benchmark_details.name: OpenLex3D
benchmark_details.overview: OpenLex3D is a dedicated benchmark to evaluate 3D open-vocabulary scene representations, providing new label annotations for 23 scenes, capturing real-world linguistic variability and introducing nuanced descriptions. It defines two evaluation tasks: open-set semantic segmentation and object retrieval.
benchmark_details.data_type: semantic segmentation and object retrieval labels

purpose_and_intended_users.goal: To provide a comprehensive evaluation of 3D scene representations using open-vocabulary semantics, capturing linguistic variability across object categories.
purpose_and_intended_users.limitations: The label set focuses on direct labels and does not account for additional object properties such as affordances, material, and color.

data.source: Human-annotated labels for 23 scenes from the Replica, ScanNet++, and HM3D datasets.
data.size: 23 scenes labeled with an average of 11 labels per object
data.annotation: Labels reviewed by four human annotators for each object.

methods: Human evaluation of segmentation and retrieval tasks
methodology.calculation: Evaluation metrics are calculated based on predicted labels and their textual features compared to ground truth.
methodology.interpretation: Top-N IoU assesses the proportion of correctly classified objects within defined categories; AP evaluates the effectiveness of retrieval tasks.
methodology.baseline_results: State-of-the-art 3D open-vocabulary methods evaluated on both tasks.
methodology.validation: Evaluation of performance across various existing models to identify strengths and weaknesses.
